skill.name: dispatching-parallel-agents
skill.description: Use when facing 2+ independent tasks that can be worked on without shared state or sequential dependencies
skill.summary: Use when facing 2+ independent tasks that can be worked on without shared state or sequential depend...
skill.author: obra

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill containing only markdown content. No executable code, scripts, network calls, filesystem access, environment variable reading, or external command execution. The skill teaches a parallel agent dispatching pattern.

content.user_title: Dispatch parallel agents for independent tasks
content.value_statement: When multiple independent problems occur, investigating them sequentially wastes time. This skill provides a pattern for dispatching multiple AI agents to work on separate problem domains concurrently, dramatically reducing investigation time.
actual_capabilities: Identify independent problem domains that can run in parallel
Structure focused agent prompts with clear scope and constraints
Dispatch multiple agents to work on separate tasks simultaneously
Review and integrate parallel agent results without conflicts
limitations: Only works when tasks have no shared state or sequential dependencies
Cannot help when failures are related and might affect each other
Does not execute code or directly modify files
Requires human to verify agent changes before integration

use_cases.title: Fix multiple failing tests
use_cases.description: Dispatch parallel agents to fix test files with different root causes, reducing debugging time significantly

use_cases.title: Investigate distributed failures
use_cases.description: Send agents to investigate separate subsystems independently when multiple services fail simultaneously

use_cases.title: Parallel feature implementation
use_cases.description: Have agents work on independent features or bug fixes in different code areas at the same time

prompt_templates.title: Basic parallel dispatch
prompt_templates.prompt: Task: Fix the 3 failing tests in src/agents/agent-tool-abort.test.ts. The failures are: 1) 'should abort tool with partial output capture' expects 'interrupted at' in message. 2) 'should handle mixed completed and aborted tools' - fast tool aborted instead of completed. 3) 'should properly track pendingToolCount' expects 3 results but gets 0. These are timing/race condition issues. Return a summary of what you found and fixed.

prompt_templates.title: Multiple independent domains
prompt_templates.prompt: Fix the failures in src/batch/batch-completion-behavior.test.ts: 2 tests failing where tools are not executing properly. Focus on understanding why tools in batch completions are being skipped. Read the test file, identify the event structure issue, and fix it. Return a summary of root cause and changes made.

prompt_templates.title: Race condition focus
prompt_templates.prompt: Fix the race condition in src/tools/tool-approval-race-conditions.test.ts where execution count equals 0 instead of expected value. This is an async timing issue. Replace arbitrary timeouts with event-based waiting. Return: Summary of the root cause, the fix applied, and verification that tests pass.

prompt_templates.title: Integration review
prompt_templates.prompt: Three agents just completed parallel work on different test files. Read the summary files each agent created: /tmp/agent1-summary.md, /tmp/agent2-summary.md, /tmp/agent3-summary.md. Check for conflicts between their changes, verify the fixes make sense together, and run the full test suite to confirm all pass.

output_examples.input: Fix the 3 failing tests in agent-tool-abort.test.ts that involve timing issues
output: ✓ Agent dispatched for timing-related test failures
• Scope: Single test file with focused problem domain
• Constraints: Replace timeouts with event-based waiting
• Expected: Summary of root cause and specific fix applied
• Next step: Review changes before integration

best_practices: Group failures by independent problem domains before dispatching agents
Give each agent specific scope, clear goals, and explicit constraints
Require agents to return summaries so you can verify their changes
anti_patterns: Dispatching agents for related failures that might affect each other
Giving agents vague scope like 'fix all the tests' instead of specific files
Skipping the integration review step after agents return

faq.question: What makes tasks suitable for parallel dispatch?
faq.answer: Tasks must have no shared state, no sequential dependencies, and independent problem domains. Each agent can complete without affecting others.

faq.question: How many agents can I dispatch at once?
faq.answer: The skill recommends 3+ independent failures for effective parallel dispatch. More agents means more coordination overhead to review.

faq.question: How does this integrate with Claude Code?
faq.answer: Use the Task() function to dispatch multiple agents. Each task runs concurrently. Agents work on their assigned scope independently.

faq.question: What data do agents have access to?
faq.answer: Each agent only has access to files and context within its assigned problem domain. This isolation prevents interference between agents.

faq.question: What if agents make conflicting changes?
faq.answer: The review step catches conflicts before integration. Assigning independent domains minimizes overlap. Run full test suite to verify compatibility.

faq.question: How is this different from sequential agent use?
faq.answer: Sequential agents wait for each task to complete before starting the next. Parallel dispatch runs independent investigations simultaneously, reducing total investigation time.
